title: dead *update pic's*
content:
yesterday i found out that my old keenomatic has died
it had been in in a lot of parts a friend and i were looking to get some parts back in we took out the motherboard and i noticed that the battery had leaked [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-sad.gif[/img]
the battery looks a lot like this
[img]http://img.photobucket.com/albums/v177/memsys/battery.png[/img]

my mom called some one and he still had some keenomatic's left so after a few hours he came with 2 486 that both run like a charm [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-grin.gif[/img] i worked at least 4 hours adding ram trying the cpu from the dead motherboard it still works
the one that is in it now is a 50mhz model the cpu from the dead pc 88mhz but it get's too hot so i need a heat because the active heat sink from the old pc is connected to the psu [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-stoned.gif[/img]
photo's are here [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-grin.gif[/img]

Tom Hall: "If I owned Keen, there sure would be. I don't consider that GBA game canon by any means."

title: Re: dead
content:
At work a lot of our computers are dying due to incorrectly made condensors used on the motherboards.
They never showed any problems, until suddenly one had a problem, and another, and another, and so on.
Opening them up you can see the condensors looking bloated and leaking.
This means we've had a lot of motherboard replacements.
Not really the same thing, or relevant, but I felt like replying in this thread. :P

Indeed, good thing that you got a replacement quickly.
Broken computers aren't much fun at all. [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-sad.gif[/img] Retodon8
Sheep happens! [url=http://keen.retodon8.net/][img]http://retodon8.net/Keen/Graphics/K1_nme_Yorp.gif[/img][/url]

title: problem
content:
i did't want to post a new topic for my problem
the problem is that dos uses an other keyboard layout then my keyboard how do i fix this ?[url=http://profile.xfire.com/memsys][img]http://miniprofile.xfire.com/bg/bg/type/2/memsys.png[/img][/url]

title: Re: dead
content:
Retodon8: At work a lot of our computers are dying due to incorrectly made condensors used on the motherboards

You mean capacitors? There's a pretty widespread problem with those, we've just replaced 11 PCs at work because of the problem. Dell seems to be the worst affected.

memsys: the problem is that dos uses an other keyboard layout then my keyboard how do i fix this

Look up keyb.com (or country.sys, depending on which DOS version you're using.)

title: Re: dead
content:
Yeah, capacitors of course, sorry. [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-smile.gif[/img]
As a matter of fact it's the Dells for us too.

I spoke with two people from the company that repairs them for us, and one of them told me it's actually not just Dells that have use these faulty capacitors.
(We buy a new, large batch of systems every now and again, and this batch happened to be all Dells, other systems are either newer or older, and don't have any problems.)
He also mentioned talk online about the capacitor manufacturer having stolen the plans from a rival manufacturer, but ending up missing part of the plans, resulting in a semi-working product.
Just internet buzz of course, and I haven't searched about it myself, but an interesting story at least.
Alias just is more exciting than work. [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-smile.gif[/img]
The other person told me they get a lot of extra computers to fix each month, I think she said 80, but don't hold it against me if I'm wrong, and that's just the one company.Retodon8
Sheep happens! [url=http://keen.retodon8.net/][img]http://retodon8.net/Keen/Graphics/K1_nme_Yorp.gif[/img][/url]

title: Re: dead
content:
I heard that the problem was the company accidentally used the wrong materials when building the capacitors in an attempt to save money (which could explain why so many of them ended up in Dells, to reduce the price just that little bit more.) Anyway, as far as I'm aware it's the entire GX270/SX270 series and some GX280s that are affected.

[url=http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Capacitor_plague]Wikipedia[/url] has a bit about this in general, and [url=http://www.badcaps.net/]badcaps.net[/url] has some info too.
